story:
Once upon a time, in a small village in Indonesia, there was a kind and curious little boy named Sari. He lived with his mother, father, and baby sister in a cozy house near the rice fields.

Sari loved to explore the village and learn about all the different animals that lived there. His favorite animal was the hornbill, a beautiful bird with a long, curved beak. Sari would often see hornbills flying high above the treetops, and he dreamed of one day seeing one up close.

One day, Sari's mother told him a story about the mythical hornbill palace, hidden deep in the forest. She said that the palace was home to the king and queen of all the hornbills, and that it was filled with precious gems and golden treasures.

Sari's eyes widened with excitement. "Can we go and see it, mother?" he asked.

His mother smiled and shook her head. "The hornbill palace is very hard to find, Sari. Only those who are pure of heart and have a good soul can find it."

Sari was determined to prove that he was worthy of seeing the hornbill palace. He spent every day helping his neighbors and doing good deeds for those in need. He was kind to all the animals in the village, and soon, he became known as the kindest and most helpful little boy in the village.

One day, as Sari was walking through the forest, he heard a faint tapping sound. He followed the sound until he came upon a large tree, and to his surprise, he saw a hornbill pecking at the bark.

Sari approached the hornbill slowly, speaking softly so as not to scare it away. The hornbill looked at him with its bright, intelligent eyes, and Sari felt a connection to the bird.

He spoke to the hornbill, telling it about his dream to see the hornbill palace. To his surprise, the hornbill nodded its head as if it understood him.

The hornbill led Sari deeper into the forest, flying from tree to tree, until they came upon a hidden valley. In the center of the valley stood a magnificent palace made of gleaming gold and encrusted with precious gems.

Sari's eyes widened with amazement as he took in the sight of the hornbill palace. The hornbill king and queen welcomed him with open wings, and Sari was invited to join them for a feast.

Sari spent the night in the hornbill palace, eating delicious fruits and learning about the history and culture of the hornbills. He felt honored and grateful to have been given the opportunity to see such a wondrous place.

When it was time to leave, the hornbill king and queen gave Sari a special gift: a small hornbill feather, imbued with the magic of the hornbill palace. They told him that the feather would bring him good luck and protect him from harm.

Sari thanked the hornbills and returned to his village, where he was greeted with cheers and congratulations. He had proven that with kindness, determination, and a good heart, anything was possible.

From that day on, Sari lived his life with even more kindness and compassion, spreading joy and happiness wherever he went. And whenever he needed a little extra luck, he would take out the hornbill feather and remember his magical journey to the hornbill palace.

The end.

Goodnight, my dear son. May your dreams be filled with wonder and magic, just like Sari's.
